												Control a floating black puffball through a gauntlet of things that want to kill it. The developers came up with a lot of great ideas to flesh out this concept. The powerups are imaginative and fun, and the level design works with them beautifully. The best stages are a blast to play through as you bounce through rapidly-spinning gears or navigate a whole swarm of puffballs through a shredding machine. Only one may survive, but hey, that's all you need!I wish I could end the review here and give this my recommendation. Unfortunately, about 30% of the levels in the second half of the game take place in near or complete darkness. You have to navigate through mazes with no feedback except the glowing eyes of your puffball failing to move towards the right as they bump up against an invisible wall. Then you die and start over - yes, there's a time limit of just a few seconds.Some levels pull this dark maze trick off, but it's only fun when you're controlling a whole swarm of puffballs, and you can use them as a sort of "throwing flour on a ghost" trick to work out where the walls are. But there were numerous times where I had no such option available and had to just (literally) bang my head against a wall until I found the correct path. BADLAND is a good game with a major flaw that comes up far too often. On the plus side, they are very generous with save points and you do have the ability to skip sections you've failed multiple times. If you play this, you'll get a lot of enjoyment, but also a great deal of frustration.

												Badland is gameplay-wise a wholesome, simplistic, and very fun sidescroller, which will occupy you for a long time with its uniquely challenging puzzles. But on the side of art design and atmosphere it is on a whole new level, rivaling some of the best indie games out there. It has a level of professionalism rarely seen in iOS to PC ports, and a level of immersion and beauty rarely seen in games as a whole.Gameplay:Badland is not mechanically deep, nor does it need to be. The gameplay is simple: get your small flying creature to the end of the level. There are puzzles, level geometry, and machines which stand in your way, and powerups which can serve as either a benefit or a hassle, and the levels dramatically increase in difficulty. Originally released on iOS devices, Badland was controllable with one button (or more accurately, one touch), but for this Game of the Year release, it has been rebalanced for a new control scheme allowing the player to move in any direction, with levels modified to accommodate, which adds an extra layer of depth and challenge. The controls feel incredibly fluid and smooth, and the game makes use of a realistically applied physics engine to increase the vivid, immersive feel of the movement and the game itself. There are even multiplayer and coop modes, local and playable with up to four players on one keyboard.This game gets much harder than you’d think!Art:Badland is artistically beautiful, with gorgeous background art, highly detailed level design, and incredible sound design, the latter of which is some of the best I've heard in any game. It immerses you in an atmospheric world of nature and beauty and mysterious machines. The silhouette level design reminds me of Limbo, but has its own unique feel within the context of this game as well.The story is told by the images in the background and how they evolve over time. Eventually you begin to question the world you are in, what happened to make it like this, and what role this small creature has to play. The atmosphere is sometimes peaceful and sometimes rather creepy. The visual art and level design are supplemented by the incredible sound design, immersive, ambient and very realistic. This is a great game to put on nice headphones, sit back and relax, and play, and it has a feature called “Flow Mode” which provides uninterrupted gameplay and minimalistic, text-free UI which is gorgeous and one of my favorite things about this game.Negatives:Here is the short list of things I don’t like about this version of the game. They are mostly just immersion-breaking more than anything else.-Achievement notifications: Steam has its own achievement notifications, but Badland adds another: a banner that covers the top portion of the screen and breaks immersion. I’m not a fan of that, but it’s only there for a couple seconds.-Camera: yes it is a sidescroller, and therefore the camera is supposed to be my enemy, but it still isn’t easy when the threat of the left wall of the screen is always directly behind you and you never get to look at the middle or right side of your monitor.In all:Badland was a standout showpiece on the iOS market, a place filled with the scum of the game industry, but here on Steam I can see that it will likely stand out less among more popular indie games. This is why I encourage you to get it: it’s a lovely experience, a wonderfully fun puzzle game, and a beautiful audiovisual presentation, and not something to be missed.

												BADLAND is a casual game made by studio Frogmind. You take control of a flappy furball animal somewhere deep in the forest where odd things happen because of alien machines full of traps. Well, actually, you take control of more than one furball, as almost every level will grant you the option of cloning them! Tens or hundreds or furballs that you will control with one button!The controls are really easy and intuitive - you have a button to flap (with all your furballs) and you just choose the direction of movement. You can do this either with your keyboard or gamepad (Xbox 360 controller worked flawlessly). To be not too much casual, this game will push on you by moving screen to the right - any furball that goes off-screen dies. But don't get discouraged, the game isn't made to be hard and there are usually checkpoints before and after more demanding parts of levels.You might think this is the extended version of popular mobile game Flappy Bird (made by Dong Nguyen in 2013), and you might be actually right - the main gameplay element is same, with added furball clones, specific gameplay changing mutators like faster sidescrolling or furball size change, and beautiful visual style based on silhouettes that you may know from LIMBO (made by Playdead in 2011).The game offers huge amount of content, as there are hundred levels optimised for both singleplayer and local multiplayer (there are just smaller differences between SP and MP levels). But that's not all, there are also thousands of custom levels!Even though BADLAND is originally a smartphone game, it didn't get just ported, it got a rework with focus on many details to feel great on PC. There are still new updates with even more content and bugfixes, it's great to see active indie developers. BADLAND fully deserves recommendation for what it is - entertaining sidescroller with beautiful graphics.

Basic InformationTitle:  BADLAND: Game of the Year EditionStatus:  ReleasedDeveloper:  FrogmindPublisher:  FrogmindGenre:  Side-ScrollerRelease Date:  26th of May, 2015Type:  Single-player and Local Co-OpGeneral ImpressionBADLAND was a mobile gaming hit sensation when it launched in 2013 for Android and iOS terminals. I should know, since I really enjoyed playing it back then as I still do now, through Steam. If you would be unfamiliar to mobile gaming, you might make a mistake in thinking that BADLAND has inspired itself from Flappy Bird, also a game from the spring of 2013. That one launched nearly two months after BADLAND and it’s inferior to it in nearly all regards except for an even higher scale of difficulty. It was most fortunate that the success of their project, convinced Frogmind to release the title on all gaming platforms in 2015. From consoles to Windows, Linux and even relatively obscure operating systems such as the ones implemented by Kindle and BlackBerry. If those aren’t clear signs of this game’s popularity and quality, I don’t know what else might be. Over 10 million BADLAND downloads through the Google Play Store alone, says it all.I rarely have any words of praise for mobile games since the vast majority are little more than lazy attempts and/or cash grabs. It would be a massive blunder if you’d judge BADLAND from the same perspective. It is among those 10% of all mobile games that can entertain and never feel like a time waste, while also featuring a more than decent production value. So why did I compare it to Flappy? Well in BADLAND you also use pressure sensitive controls (or button-mashing for keyboards) in order to traverse levels through flight and obstacle avoiding. Control scheme itself is simple to understand but a bit harder to master on later levels that involve both speed and precision. You can jump-start our furry protagonist(s) with either the W key or Up and maneuver across the stage with A, D or Left and Right. The level design itself is both a blessing and a curse. Apart from the razor-sharp spinning wheels, lazers, moving gears and falling rocks which will instantly kill you, special care must be taken in regards to the haste and agility with which you must fly, tumble, roll through the level from start and all the way to it’s vacuum finish. The stage moves independently of your maneuvers so you fail and have to restart to the nearest checkpoint (mercifully, those are always in ample supply), unless you hurry up constantly. That gameplay mechanic by itself, sets it apart from your run-of-the-mill puzzle/platformers. Coupled with other features such as the possibility to control multiple furries (I call them that, but they aren’t really describable in animal terms) or clones, in your attempt to pass the stage with as many of them by your side. In some instances, you will need to use them to activate power-ups that can enlarge or shrink them enough to pass through narrow spaces or demolish obstacles with their increased weight. Not a dull moment in sight.And that would be impossible since the game’s popular with not only gamers or game journalists but most importantly folks who dedicate some of their spare time, in creating new and exciting levels for all BADLAND players to test out and enjoy. This wouldn’t be a GOTY version on Steam if collectors of all types were neglected, am I right? Achievements and Trading Cards are just the cherries on top of a cake that was more than fine even without them. You can’t go wrong if you purchase this title even outside of Steam Sales. Sure, you can still play the game on your smartphone for free but developers such as Frogmind deserve our full support. And hopefully we shall have BADLAND 2 on the Steam Store soon enough.Strong Points+ Beautiful art style and relaxing sounds.+ Seemingy simple yet addictive gameplay that is never repetitive.+ Huge replay value through user-created content.+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.Weak Points- A bit  too difficult at times.Rating 90/100  This review was submitted for ReviewExperts, through the generous contribution of Daniël - REX ♥ Gaming.

												Badland is one of those games that, at a glance, seems like it must be good. Visually, it's very impressive. It has simple core gameplay with some neat mechanics. Unfortunately, after giving this game chance after chance, I'd have to say that none of that means this game is actually any good.It's not all about the controls, but that's as fair a place as any to start. Trying to control your fluffy blob thing is a chore - it feels like simply to play the game you have to fight a constant battle against the controls. In open space, it isn't utterly terrible, but if you have the misfortune of contacting any background object? Anything could happen, and in this game, 'anything' generally means you end up falling off the left side of the screen to your death. This is especially an issue when you run into a 'puzzle'. There are basically two kinds of puzzles: one where you have to die repeatedly smashing yourself into the environment to figure out what part of it moves, and one where you know immediately what you have to do but trying to actually convince the controls to do that takes a frustratingly large number of attempts. Neither are particularly innovative.Now, to be fair, I haven't even mentioned the wide variety of powerups you can get. You can get a wide variety of powerups, most of which are used purely for the riveting gameplay of 'pick up exactly the right powerups or you die'. There are also 'clone' and 'superclone' powerups which give you a small (or large) army of fluffy blobs, and the levels that essentially amount to 'send your army of dudes through this obstacle course at high speed' are actually moderately fun. Far too often, though, having multiple dudes just means you'll eventually have to try to control multiple dudes at once (remember the controls? yeah, they're terrible) to do different things. This exponential misery is especially great because there's no way to actually control them separately - often you're reduced to smashing several dudes at a dividing point and hoping they end up going down different paths so that they can do whatever they need to do to advance you in the level.There's also a fairly well-documented phenomenon where the background of the level becomes extremely dark, which as you might imagine makes everything worse. I have no idea whether it's a bug, but every time I experienced it, restarting the game caused it to stop happening.The last straw (not as in 'the straw that broke the camel's back', as in the last chronological straw piled on the back of a camel that is already dead oh god why are you adding more straws) came when I decided that I would play through the entire game before reviewing it, regardless of how painful that might be, so that I could really give a complete picture of the game, and just in case it somehow magically became a good game right near the end. I fought my way to the next-to-last level (lasers, by the way, are quite a nice mechanic and it's a shame they're only in the last few levels), got a fair distance into it, and the game crashed to desktop. I opened it up again, got a bit farther this time, and it crashed again. I opened it up a third time, and it immediately crashed the first time I tried to pause.So, I mean, if you want a game to look at, it's great. If you want good gameplay, on the other hand, you might be better off looking elsewhere.Honestly, though, even if you really think you want this game, just get the (free) mobile version. I wouldn't be surprised if the controls are smoother there as well.

												I've had Badland on Android since 2014, but finally picked up the PC version in a Humble Bundle. I was hopeful that playing multiplayer on a television with controllers would be better than having everyone crowded around a tablet, and I was right! Below is what I wrote about it back in 2014[medium.com]:At first glance you might want to call Badland an infinite flyer. But there are enough major differences that I do not think it quite fits. Much like infinite flyers, you have one basic control: touch to fly up, don’t touch to drop down. However, in most infinite flyers touching anything results in death. In Badland there are many things that will kill you, but usually the floor and ceiling are safe. Instead the game is based around set obstacles that you must get past.There are two main ways to lose. Contact with objects like saws, lasers, or getting squished between two otherwise harmless objects will kill you. Falling behind the camera also results in failure. Usually the camera continues forward at a slow but unstoppable pace. There are exceptions, like during maze sections where the camera will kindly wait for you to complete the puzzle. Failure is not the end of the world like most infinite flyers. Instead the game is riddled with checkpoints, usually placed right before each obstacle or puzzle.Badland spices things up with power ups found throughout levels. Some make you smaller, some bigger, some bouncy, some sticky, etc. Usually they are strategically placed to help you get past the next obstacle. As with any good puzzle game, Badland takes the limited number of different elements and combines them in new, more challenging ways as the game progresses to keep itself fresh.I have never played a game with a setting quite like Badland’s. It is a jungle world with pieces of abandoned advanced technology lying about. You see this world as a small creature trying to survive the day in this deadly world. The art style does a great job of presenting this beautiful world. The backgrounds are vividly colored, seemingly handpainted panoramas of huge objects in the distance. The objects in the foreground (as in, everything that you interact with in the game) are almost completely black. You might think that the background would distract from the important objects, but it did not. In fact, I only noticed things in the background if I was in an area with a lull in obstacles. I started to imagine what kinds of events might be happening on this world, what awesome sci-fi adventures were happening that my little fuzzy animal was completely unaware of. I also thought about all the hilarious ways that this little animal’s journey might be inadvertently affecting the world around it.There is no soundtrack to speak of in Badland. Instead, ambient jungle sounds permeate quietly throughout. Many obstacles make sounds, such as the buzzing of a saw or the sizzle of a laser. Honestly I did not miss the existence of a soundtrack until I looked in my humble library and realized that the game came with no music.There are 70 levels (not including community-made levels,) divided into different times of day. They of course get progressively more difficult. There are also goals besides simply reaching the end of a level. Throughout many levels you can get power ups that clone the little creature. The more clones that make it to the end, the better. It becomes very difficult to keep them all alive however, because they all obey your command to go up or down at the same time. Each level has three different objectives to complete, such as saving a certain number of creatures or collecting all the power ups in the level. It is the kind of game that I have enjoyed completing, but I doubt I will ever fully beat it.There is also a hilarious local multiplayer mode where up to four people control different creatures making their way through the same level together. It is competitive, so whoever makes it farthest wins. This multiplayer mode works best on larger screens, and it is the first game that I can think of that makes perfect sense to play on Android TV.

												This game is great!  For those who have played the app, the game is almost the same, with the same levels as far as I can tell. Controls for left and right have been added (and the levels have been slightly modified to accommodate), but the gameplay feels the same. The levels still constantly scroll, meaning the puzzles remain intact.  Multiplayer becomes much easier when everyone has a controller and doesn't have to huddle around a tablet screen.You play as a cute species of creatures navigating their way through a forest being overtaken with machines. There's an implication of a storyline, but it doesn't have a resolution (yet?). I'm hoping the developers will come out with a definitive ending to the adventure in the future. In the past they have mentioned that more levels are planned.The controls are extremely simple, but the gameplay becomes very difficult. You will die a lot, but every time you lose you are only sent back a few seconds earlier in the level, so it never becomes too frustrating. The puzzles are clever, and many are based on trial and error.  The sounds and graphics are spectacular, and provide an immersive experience when you play with headphones.The multiplayer aspect of the game (it's 4 player) is very well thought out. Those who have played more will consistently defeat beginners in the competitive mode, but in the cooperative mode, everyone has fun regardless of skill level. When you die, your teammates will either revive you within a few seconds, or everyone will die, starting at the previous checkpoint with everyone back again, so no one gets frustrated, and everyone feels like they’re contributing. It's entertaining to watch, and there's a lot of discussion because teamwork becomes essential as the difficulty increases.I highly recommend this game! If you have the app and only play single player, you won't see much by way of new content. But if you play multiplayer, it works much better here. If you don't have the app, this game is a must!

Badland is gameplay-wise a wholesome, simplistic, and very fun sidescroller, which will occupy you for a long time with its uniquely challenging puzzles. But on the side of art design and atmosphere it is on a whole new level, rivaling some of the best indie games out there. It has a level of professionalism rarely seen in iOS to PC ports, and a level of immersion and beauty rarely seen in games as a whole.Gameplay:Badland is not mechanically deep, nor does it need to be. The gameplay is simple: get your small flying creature to the end of the level. There are puzzles, level geometry, and machines which stand in your way, and powerups which can serve as either a benefit or a hassle, and the levels dramatically increase in difficulty. Originally released on iOS devices, Badland was controllable with one button (or more accurately, one touch), but for this Game of the Year release, it has been rebalanced for a new control scheme allowing the player to move in any direction, with levels modified to accommodate, which adds an extra layer of depth and challenge. The controls feel incredibly fluid and smooth, and the game makes use of a realistically applied physics engine to increase the vivid, immersive feel of the movement and the game itself. There are even multiplayer and coop modes, local and playable with up to four players on one keyboard.This game gets much harder than you’d think! But I totally recommend you playing in Co-op with friends having on your TV with big picture mode with controllers! Playing with friends take the game to the next level and makes it more fun. Art:Badland is artistically beautiful, with gorgeous background art, highly detailed level design, and incredible sound design, the latter of which is some of the best I've heard in any game. It immerses you in an atmospheric world of nature and beauty and mysterious machines. The silhouette level design reminds me of Limbo, but has its own unique feel within the context of this game as well.The story is told by the images in the background and how they evolve over time. Eventually you begin to question the world you are in, what happened to make it like this, and what role this small creature has to play. The atmosphere is sometimes peaceful and sometimes rather creepy. The visual art and level design are supplemented by the incredible sound design, immersive, ambient and very realistic. This is a great game to put on nice headphones, sit back and relax, and play, and it has a feature called “Flow Mode” which provides uninterrupted gameplay and minimalistic, text-free UI which is gorgeous and one of my favorite things about this game. Badland is truly a must try game with stunning visuals, awesome gameplay supporting 4 player co-op, Steam Achievements & Steam Trading cards support! GO FOR IT!!! 9/10

												badland is in an incredible fun and unqiue game with challenging but enjoyable gameplay.Badland is a mobile port. I have played the original and I thoroughly enjoyed it on android and I thorughly enjoyed it on there. Having played this version I was very sceptical about it being released on PC. The controls of the game on mobile are extremely simple. All you do is tap the screen to go up and let go to go down. I didn't think this would work out well for a PC game.What badlands does to combat this problem is introduce a simple but definitely well needed feature. They make it so you can go left and right. You may think I seem completely crazy even advertising this as a feature, but trust me, without it the game would feel so bland on PC. As far as I can see the levels have also been edited to go with this change and you do need to use the movement to get to certain parts of the level. Not as much as I would have hoped though. The majority of the game you do still only use up. Which can make the game drag at some points. Outside of the trailer the game has no story. The trailer basically tells the story of them being clones and that is about it. I would have personally liked some kind of basic story but it isn't entirely necessary. You should definitely watch that trailer by the way because it is incredible!The challenge of the game is provided by use of obstacles and power ups. The screen moves along automatically. You need to try and keep up with this. If your character ends up going off the screen you will fail. There are also obstacles with spikes and such to avoid as well  and these get increasingly hard to avoid as you go along through the game. Pretty standard gameplay really but it still does what it needs to do well.But the real thing that gets the gameplay going is the powerups. You start the game with a few standard power ups that you can pick up during levels. These include size powerups to make your clone bigger or smaller, clone powerups to make copies of yourself and many more. You unlock more as you go throughout the game. The powerups are necessary for you to progress through the levels and you need to make sure to use them correctly to progress. This adds a real great element to the standard gameplay presented.Now what you will probably notice immediately is the incredible graphics the game has. It adds a real nice style and nice depth of colour to the gameplay. Many of the levels give a very dark vibe and then others give a nice colourful vibe. These contrast well with each other. I'm not certain, but I believe the PC version also has had a high upgrade in the graphics and looks way better.The biggest problem I found with badland is the laziness of parts of the mobile port. The menu seems to have just been ported straight over, without being edited, from mobile. This means that to navigate parts of the menu you have to slide your mouse accross the screen. While this method of control works great on mobile it isn't nice to have to do this with a mouse. You then just have the fact that the menu looks extremely mobile like. I mean the buttons are rather simplified to fit with a small screen on mobile. You even have a facebook and twitter button. The options menu does mostly stick with this trend as well. Initially the only option your presented with is a sound slider. It is only one slider and there are no seperate sliders for music and sounds or anything else. You do also have a very basic graphics options menu. This includes HD graphics, bloom, V-sync and fullscreen. But there are no resolution options or other customizable graphics options. There is also a controls menu with completely rebindable keys.Overall I have to say that I did thoroughly enjoy playing badland and will definitely go back to it and enjoy the highly challenging gameplay. I am nowhere near to completing it and I can only imagine it will get much harder. I would definitely recommend it to any fan of a challenging platformer. And the price is cheap for it as well!TheIronicGamers rating system Don't ever buy this game. Maybe consider it on a sale. An average game.A good game that should definitely be considered.A must play!Disclaimer: I was provided with a free review copy by the developer to right this review with.

												Badland GOTY edtion.... what ?not another GOTY game... ? yes... but its worth it, if you havent already got the game in your libary YES.... What a wonderful looking game.. yes it's the great looking, simple but great. Think of Limbo, but with colour. You start of with your character Clony, blinking at you waiting for your to bring him/her to life. With a click of the key/button, Clony starts to fly up ....keep pressing.... Clony flys high... but you also need to move to the right. Yes Badland is a side scroller. You need to navigate through the badland... You have to move around moving cogs, spike bombs and many more interseting things. As you move towards the levels end you met other Clony on your way. This is were it might sound like a nightmare.... but you will have to offer some of them, to give yourself a chance to complete the level. Talking of levels, there are 100 levels, divided over four times of day, Day/Noon/Dust/Night. The level change depending on the time of day. There are over 300 missions included... and no I have gotten that far yet. With regards to achievements there are 77 within the game. So there is also something there if you an achievement hunter. Badland also has 3 different game types, single player, co op and  mutliplayer. I have yet to try the last two, but hopefully will get the chance to. So is Badland worth your money, Yes. Should you buy it, I would say yes. Badland Game of the Year Edition that was released in May 2015 for PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation Vita, Xbox One, Wii U and Steam for Linux, Microsoft Windows and OS X. So there should be a platform for everyone, whatever your favorite is.
